title: Comparisons
text: Outputs on this page compare “Past” conditions with “Present” conditions. Results here are intended for exploration and illumination of issues to explore further. As noted on the “Present” page there are differences in the classification scheme so direct comparisons should be viewed with caution.

title: Comparisons
text:
Summary
There has not been broad whole conversion of ecosystems from one to another (explore circular chord diagram below). However, due to harvests, fire suppression and other management actions (in addtion to changes in natural processes) there have been some notable changes in succession classes (see “Succession classes for most dominant Biophysical Settings”) section below:

Perhaps the most interesting broad-scale change is conversion of ‘conifer’ types to ‘hardwood’, presumably due to fire suppression.
Some ecosystems have sizable over/under-representation of successin classes on the landscape today compared to modeled historic. For example:

Laurentian-Acadian Northern Hardwoods Forest - Hemlock is missing succession class D
Classes A-C under represented in the Boreal Jack Pine-Black Spruce Forest - Pine Barrens
Class A and B under reprented in the Boreal Acidic Peatland Systems


These differences may or may not be ‘real’ on the ground and/or may not be a management priority.

title: Hiawatha National Forest Ecological Assessment, 2023
text:
In general we will use LANDFIRE and Center for Resilient Conservation Science products to:

Map and summarize past and present ecosystems and ecosystem conditions
Explore historical disturbance regimes
Summarize patterns of change and management opportunities
Present maps of landscape-scale connectivity and resilient sites

Outputs presented here are the tip of the iceberg of what can be done with these datasets and are intended to help begin brainstorming about appropriate questions that could be explored collaboratively.

title: Hiawatha National Forest Ecological Assessment, 2023
text:
Location of this assessment
The assessment area is essentially the Hiawatha National Forest Proclamation Boundary plus a 1 mile buffer (supplied by Sam Adams, GIS coordinator).

title: Interpretation
text: Ecosystem specific observations

title: Past
text: LANDFIRE’s Biophysical Settings (BpSs, aka “Historical Ecosystems”) represent “the vegetation system that may have been dominant on the landscape prior to Euro-American settlement and is based on both the current biophysical environment and an approximation of the historical disturbance regime.” (from https://landfire.gov/bps.php). We will use this data to explore the most prevalent BpSs in a chart and map, and also the historical disturbance data that are linked to the BpSs.

title: Past
text:
Summary
Historically 10 historical ecosystems covered roughly 90% of the Hiawatha National Forest. More specifically:

Wetland types (primarily the ‘Laurentian-Acadian Alkaline Conifer-Hardwood Swamp’ and ‘Boreal Acidic Peatland Systems’) were present on > 40% of the area.
The ‘Laurentian-Acadian Northern Hardwoods Forest-Hemlock’ ecosystem covered ~20% of the area
Roughly 30% of the Hiawatha had ecosytems with Mean Fire Return Intervals (MFRI) of ~100 years or less, with ~10% having a MFRI of > 10 years. There was roughly 18k acres of surface fire per year historically. Wind/weather/stress was the second-most common disturbance, impacting roughly 7k acres per year.

title: Present
text: All outputs on this page generated with the most recent LANDFIRE Existing Vegetation Type, Cover and Height datasets, which represent conditions on the ground in 2020.

title: Present
text:
Summary
In general the Hiawatha National Forest, as of 2020, had not experienced substantial conversion of natural ecosystems to developed or agricultural types, though there are some patterns to note:

It is tempting to directly compare the past and present maps-do so with caution as the classification system has been modified.
Wetlands are still dominant regardless of classification system.
The aspen-birch EVT that was mapped in 2020 may have been a succession class in the historical ecosystems. It is not clear from this analysis alone if this type has changed in extent, or not.
There are considerable amounts of fire-dependent ecosystems, such as the ‘Jack Pine-Red Pine’. Many of these pixels are adjacent to wetland types that can burn under the right conditions.

title: Looking forward
text: There are many ways to explore what a landscape might look like in the future. Below are maps of datasets produced by the Center for Resilient Conservation Science that help us assess “the stage” so to speak, or the potential of a landscape to cope with climate change. Exploring places where resiliency, connectivity and management opportunities line up may help hedge against climate stressors.

title: Looking forward
text:
Summary
There are many ways to explore what a landscape might look like in the future. Below are maps of datasets produced by the Center for Resilient Conservation Science that help us assess “the stage” so to speak, or the potential of a landscape to cope with climate change. Exploring places where resiliency, connectivity and management opportunities line up may help hedge against climate stressors.

title: Looking forward
text:
Resilient Sites
“A site’s Resilience Score estimates its capacity to maintain species diversity and ecological function as the climate changes. It was determined by evaluating and quantifying physical characteristics that foster resilience, particularly the site’s landscape diversity and local connectedness. The score is calculated within ecoregions based on all cells of the same geophysical setting and is described on a relative basis as above or below the average.” (From https://maps.tnc.org/resilientland/coreConcepts.html)

title: Looking forward
text:
Connectivity
“Refers to the degree of fragmentation and strength of barriers that create resistance to movement within a landscape. A highly connected landscape promotes resilience by allowing species to move through the landscape and find suitable microclimates where they can persist. In this study, we calculate local connectedness by measuring the amount and configuration of human-created barriers like major roads, development, energy infrastructure, and industrial farming and forestry land.” (From https://maps.tnc.org/resilientland/coreConcepts.html)

title: About
text:
By Megan Dettenmaier
LANDFIRE provides 25+ national geo-spatial layers (e.g. vegetation, fuel, disturbance, etc.), databases, and ecological models that are available to the public for the U.S. and insular areas.
Our direct connection to the LANDFIRE Program offers a comprehensive range of nationwide geospatial data products that reflect current and historic conditions. These products also include ecosystem dynamic models that can be used for conservation, fire planning, and land management decisions.
LANDFIRE’s mission is to provide agency leaders and managers with a common “all-lands” data set of vegetation and wildland fire/fuels information for strategic fire and resource management planning and analysis.

 “Advancing conservation outcomes through collaborative ecosystem science”

title: About
text:
What are Biophysical Settings Products?
A Biophysical Setting (BpS) is a concept that represents the vegetation that may have been dominant on the landscape prior to European colonization of North America and is based on both the current biophysical environment and an approximation of the historical disturbance regime.
LANDFIRE collaborated with experts around the country to create a description and model for every BpS it mapped across the US.
Check out the vegetation modeling website to learn how to integrate BpS into your work.

Biophysical Settings Resources
Vegetation dynamics models: a comprehensive set for natural resource assessment and planning in the United States. Kori Blankenship, Randy Swaty, Kimberly R. Hall, Sarah Hagen, Kelly Pohl, Ayn Shlisky Hunt, Jeannie Patton, Leonardo Frid, Jim Smith





BpS Descriptions and Models information
Information about the BpS Spatial Data

title: About
text:
What are Existing Vegetation Products
‘LANDFIRE (LF) existing vegetation layers describe the following elements: Existing Vegetation Type (EVT), Existing Vegetation Canopy Cover (EVC), and Existing Vegetation Height (EVH). These layers are created using predictive landscape models based on extensive field-referenced data, satellite imagery and biophysical gradient layers using classification and regression trees.’ (from https://landfire.gov/vegetation.php)

Existing Vegetation Resources





Existing Vegetation Cover
Existing Vegetation Height
Existing Vegetation Type

title: About
section: Intersections: LANDFIRE Supports Certified Sustainable Forest Management
text:
Intersections: LANDFIRE Supports Certified Sustainable Forest Management
In 2022, members of the Conservation Data Lab used the Ataya Forest Tract near Knoxville, TN as an example landscape for conducting a comprehensive GIS analysis. They compared historical conditions to the current state of the forest while incorporating LANDFIRE’s departure and BpS data (among others). This tutorial provides procedures for forest managers to conduct (similar) analyses using LANDFIRE data.
Check out the guide.


 “Ataya is of conservation interest due to the relatively high connectivity, large average land parcel size and projected climate change resiliency.” 


Map by Keith Phelps

title: Hiawatha National Forest Ecological Assessment, 2023
section: Interacting with this web-hosted information platform (WHIP :))
text:
Interacting with this web-hosted information platform (WHIP :))
A few notes about using this site: * This platform is web-hosted so you can simply share a link with collaborators for their review. https://rswaty.github.io/hiawatha2023/ * Maps and charts are intended to represent general patterns, and are almost always limited to most common types (e.g., ecosystems). You can use the “zoom” tool to take a closer look. * All maps, input datasets and further assistance can be obtained by contacting the author, Randy Swaty.
